subject: Re: [junit] JUnit for Unit Testing and Integration Testing seperation
msgSnippet: At IL, we use that incredibly sophisticated technique of having all our microtests in one package hierarchy, and all our storytests-using-junit in another.
messageBody:
At IL, we use that incredibly sophisticated technique of having all
our microtests in one package hierarchy, and all our
storytests-using-junit in another. That way, Eclipse is smart enough
to run the right set when I tell it to.

Hill
Mastering TDD? Try <http://www.industriallogic.com/elearning>

P.S. Yeah, I know, storytests-using-junit is odd, but the explanation
is simple: our customer team is composed entirely of folks who can
read/write/tweak java at will, are comfortable with the IDE, etc.
They still *look* FIT'ish, just with extra parens and ;'s.

On Fri, Jun 20, 2008 at 9:59 AM, milesy1981 <chrismiles@...> wrote:
> Good Afternoon,
>
> I am trying to implement a better JUnit strategy here, and I was
> wondering if anyone has any tried and test ways of seperating out
> their different classes of testing. The line here is very fuzzy
> between what is an actual unit test and what is an integration test
> and I am trying to make that much more clearer.
>
> I want to have a bunch of test cases which purely test classes in
> isolation and test that their behaivour is as expected from an API
> standpoint, but I also want another set of tests which will test the
> actual functional and integration of things like making sure the
> integration with Spring and Hibernate is actually working and as I
> expect.
>
> Has anyone done this kind of seperation here before. I am just
> looking for any methodologies for seperation of these tests in
> regards to packaging, and running them etc. I run my tests from
> maven and it would be good to run the two sets of tests seprately
> from each other.
>
> Many Thanks.
>
> Chris
>
>
